Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge is based on observations of the natural world using the senses, and scientific tools and instruments
Elaboration: Exploring what an observation is, and different ways to make observations using the 5 senses, through guided discussion

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge is based on observations of the natural world using the senses, and scientific tools and instruments
Elaboration: Viewing examples of observations, for example recorded in rock paintings, bark drawings, age-appropriate written reports, labelled drawings or photographs, to explore ways that people make and record observations

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge is based on observations of the natural world using the senses, and scientific tools and instruments
Elaboration: Listening to people involved in scientific work – such as arborists, nurses, engineers and meteorologists – and asking questions about the importance of observations in their work

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge is based on observations of the natural world using the senses, and scientific tools and instruments
Elaboration: Interacting with stories or documentaries about scientists and noticing the ways that they make their observations, such as through drawings, collections, sound recordings and photography, and how they ask questions about what they think they will observe and find

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific knowledge is based on observations of the natural world using the senses, and scientific tools and instruments
Elaboration: Recognising that astronomers use patterns of movement of celestial objects, such as stars and comets, in the sky to make predictions about future appearances

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Identifying ways that scientific knowledge is used in the care of the local environment to meet the needs of native animals and in designing supports to meet the needs of those animals, such as building frog and insect hotels and nesting boxes or recycling materials to provide habitat

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Recognising how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples observe cyclic changes of night and day length, star patterns in the sky and seasons to predict when events occur, for example following seasonal calendars such as the Gariwerd calendar of the Djab Wurrung and Jardwardjali Peoples to associate the appearance of the emu constellation with the wildflower season during September to November

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Sharing examples of how people use scientific knowledge at home, such as by listening to or viewing weather forecasts or observing weather patterns when planning family events or outings, and wearing appropriate clothing for the season

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Discussing how people manage light and sound at home to ensure that they do not disturb each other or their neighbours, such as quietly closing doors, turning down the lights, taking off shoes on wooden floors and using window coverings

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Learning from people who work with materials, such as woodworkers, product designers and artists (such as fibre artists and sculptors), about how they observe and learn about properties of materials and how they use creativity when manipulating materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Science is used by people in their daily lives, including asking questions and using patterns from observations of the world around them to make scientific predictions
Elaboration: Investigating toys and digital tools that are sound-activated or voice-activated, and engaging in guided discussions about how some devices use voice patterns to recognise the unique features of an individual’s voice or to help people manage daily activities such as turning on lights and communicating with others

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Observing fruits and vegetables and identifying them as parts of plants such as roots, flowers, fruit and leaves

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Grouping animals as vertebrates (animals that have backbones or spinal columns, such as amphibians, birds, fish, mammals and reptiles) or invertebrates (animals that have no backbones or bony skeletons inside them, such as insects, spiders, worms, snails, lobsters and jellyfish; some have outer shells while others have no hard parts in their bodies)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Recognising humans as animals, describing external features of humans, and exploring similarities to and differences with other animals

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Using magnifying glasses or digital cameras to observe and identify external features of plants, including seeds, flowers, fruits and roots, or of animals, such as eyes, body coverings, legs and wings

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Sorting collections of model animals and explaining different grouping strategies

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have observable features that can be used to group them in different ways
Elaboration: Investigating how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ observations of external features have been represented in expressions of material culture from Deep Time to today, such as through rock art or cultural dances, for example in paintings of Genyornis newtoni, a megafaunal species that lived during the most recent Ice Age

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Identifying the places where plants and animals live, including in homes and in local areas such as ponds, national parks, gardens and zoos

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Identifying what they do to look after pets or plants at home, and grouping these activities

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Identifying and comparing the needs of a variety of plants and animals, including humans, based on their own experiences

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Creating a diorama of a place a plant or animal lives, and identifying the features that enable it to meet its needs

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Recognising how cultural protocols (ethical principles that guide behaviour in particular situations when interacting with Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples and that are designed to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural and intellectual property rights) around caring for Country and Place result in the promotion, preservation and protection of living things and the environment

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have basic needs, including air, water, food and shelter; the places where they live meet those needs
Elaboration: Exploring why caring for plants and animals is important, including as sources of food and fibre

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Comparing the roots, leaves, flowers and stems of different plants

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Investigating the movement of water in plants by observing what happens when a celery stick is placed in a glass of water to which food colouring has been added

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Exploring how the 5 human sensory organs (eyes, ears, skin, nose and tongue) detect and respond to what is happening around them, and comparing the importance of sensory organs for different animals, such as in echolocation used by bats

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Exploring why animals, including humans, have different teeth and how this relates to diets (herbivores, carnivores and omnivores)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Investigating how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ observations of external features of living things, such as the way that different animals move and behave, can be represented in traditional dance

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Plants and animals have external features that perform different functions to enable their survival; in plants these features include roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, bulbs, trunks and branches while different features in animals enable them to move, breathe, eat and respond to their environment
Elaboration: Grouping animals on the basis of common features, for example identifying how different animals use their tails or comparing body coverings of different animals, such as scales, fur, hair and skin

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Observing and manipulating objects to identify the materials these are made from and recognising that some objects are made of more than one type of material

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Identifying and naming materials in the classroom, and grouping objects made of similar materials or combinations of materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Recognising that tools such as magnifying glasses enable observation in more detail

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Sorting and grouping materials based on observed properties such as colour, hardness, texture and flexibility

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Investigating the ways that Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples have constructed and continue to construct material culture (physical aspects of the objects that surround people including the creation and use of objects such as tools, housing and clothing, including the trade of articles, as well as the behaviours, norms and rituals associated with these objects) for different purposes by combining different materials, such as hafted stone artefacts (stone points that are put into a spear and secured with sinew) and eel baskets (fibre technologies crafted together, e.g. eel baskets woven by the Gunditjmara People from local river weeds and spear grass)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Creating a display of different materials, naming each material and exploring language to describe the properties of materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Objects can be made of one or more different materials; these materials have observable properties
Elaboration: Using a digital camera to collect images of objects on a materials scavenger hunt, and sorting the images into those that show objects made of one material and those that show objects made of 2 or more different materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways for particular purposes; the properties of objects and mixtures can differ from the properties of the materials from which they are made
Elaboration: Predicting and comparing how different materials can be combined for different purposes

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways for particular purposes; the properties of objects and mixtures can differ from the properties of the materials from which they are made
Elaboration: Investigating how food can be mixed to form different products such as jelly, ice cream and cake

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways for particular purposes; the properties of objects and mixtures can differ from the properties of the materials from which they are made
Elaboration: Suggesting why different parts of everyday objects such as toys and clothes are made from different materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways for particular purposes; the properties of objects and mixtures can differ from the properties of the materials from which they are made
Elaboration: Investigating the ways that Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples have constructed and continue to construct material culture for different purposes by combining different materials, for example sewing together possum pelts with sinew to make cloaks and decorating them with ochre or constructing contemporary jewellery that includes feathers, woven fibre technologies and shells

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways for particular purposes; the properties of objects and mixtures can differ from the properties of the materials from which they are made
Elaboration: Investigating how different proportions of sand and water, as examples of mixtures, can affect the construction and stability of sandcastles

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be changed physically by different actions without changing their material composition, including by bending, twisting, stretching, crushing, squashing and breaking into smaller pieces
Elaboration: Exploring how materials can be physically changed to suit a particular purpose, such as twisting strands of cotton or wool together to make the thread stronger, and folding paper to make it fly

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be changed physically by different actions without changing their material composition, including by bending, twisting, stretching, crushing, squashing and breaking into smaller pieces
Elaboration: Manipulating materials such as paper and fabric, and determining ways that these can be physically changed by scrunching, twisting or bending, or broken into smaller pieces by cutting, tearing or crushing

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be changed physically by different actions without changing their material composition, including by bending, twisting, stretching, crushing, squashing and breaking into smaller pieces
Elaboration: Crushing a stick of chalk into a powder, comparing the properties of the stick and the powder, and discussing whether it is still the same material

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be changed physically by different actions without changing their material composition, including by bending, twisting, stretching, crushing, squashing and breaking into smaller pieces
Elaboration: Investigating how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples make physical changes to natural materials to produce material culture, for example in fibre technologies (such as basketry and fishing lines), pigments (such as ochre and medicines) and timberworking (such as working saplings to form boundary markers)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Materials can be changed physically by different actions without changing their material composition, including by bending, twisting, stretching, crushing, squashing and breaking into smaller pieces
Elaboration: Creating an ‘odd one out’ game by providing samples of the same material that has been physically changed in different ways and one sample of a different material, and challenging other students to identify the odd one out

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Making and recording observations of phenomena such as changes to weather, and seasonal changes to plants such as colour and dropping of leaves, and growth of flowers and fruit

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Noticing how daily weather indicators and seasonal patterns help them to make plans for activities in their daily lives

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Exploring how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples use particular concepts of time and weather patterns to explain how things happen in the world

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Exploring how people make clothing choices using predictions of weather or knowledge of seasonal changes

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Investigating how seasonal changes affect plants and animals, including animals that hibernate and migrate

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Daily and seasonal changes in the weather and the environment can be observed and affect decisions made in everyday life
Elaboration: Recognising the extensive knowledges of daily and seasonal changes in weather patterns and landscape held by Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples, for example the use of local seasonal calendars to manage natural resources sustainably, such as knowing the best times for hunting specific animals or when certain plants are in season for harvesting

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Exploring images, models and representations of the solar system and identifying Earth and other planets, such as images or videos of Earth from space, artworks depicting space, star trail images and physical models of the solar system

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Observing that some phenomena in the sky are only visible during the day and others during the night

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Creating a class Moon diary across a month, identifying patterns in the changing shape of the Moon and making predictions

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Observing and describing short-term and longer-term patterns of events, and regular and irregular events, that occur in the sky, such as the appearance of the Moon and stars at different times of the month or year, the appearance of a full moon, and ‘blue’, ‘blood’ and ‘super’ moons

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Exploring how cultural stories of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples describe the patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon and stars

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Earth is one of 8 planets in our solar system; observing the sky reveals patterns in the changing positions of the Sun, Moon, planets and stars
Elaboration: Observing the retrograde motion of a visible planet (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter or Saturn) relative to the background stars each night for a period of time and discussing how this is explained by the oral stories of different Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander groups, for example the Wardaman People’s descriptions of this phenomenon as the old ancestor spirits walking the zodiacal path, both forwards and backwards

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Exploring why the release of helium balloons is illegal in Victoria and the alternatives to releasing balloons when celebrating special occasions

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Identifying different objects and materials that can be re-used and/or recycled, and then collecting a range of recyclable materials and re-using them to make an object, such as creating a toy or an object that can move in a particular way

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Exploring how compost can reduce the amount of food waste that is sent to landfill

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Brainstorming ways of reducing water usage and ways that water can be saved

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Exploring and asking questions about how physically changing materials helps people to re-use them in a variety of ways, and decrease waste

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Taking care of Earth’s water, land and air involves consideration of reducing, re-using and recycling materials to conserve Earth’s resources
Elaboration: Exploring where different foods grow at different times of the year and making a list of foods that are currently in season to reduce ‘food miles’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The way objects move depends on a variety of factors including their size, shape and material
Elaboration: Observing how toys move, and grouping these based on their movements

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The way objects move depends on a variety of factors including their size, shape and material
Elaboration: Observing and describing movements of different and unusually shaped objects such as blocks, tubes and boiled eggs when rolled down a slope

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The way objects move depends on a variety of factors including their size, shape and material
Elaboration: Comparing the way different-sized, similar-shaped objects such as tennis balls, golf balls, marbles and basketballs roll and bounce

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The way objects move depends on a variety of factors including their size, shape and material
Elaboration: Exploring how the material a ball is made from, such as plastic, foam, cloth or rubber, affects the way it moves

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: The way objects move depends on a variety of factors including their size, shape and material
Elaboration: Investigating how the size and shape of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ traditional educational toys for children influence the toys’ movement; for example, the ball used in marngrook, a football game played by some Aboriginal groups at gatherings and celebrations, was traditionally played with a possum-skin ball in south-western Victoria, but in some other areas the ball was made from materials such as kangaroo skin

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Observing and manipulating everyday objects such as playground equipment, toys, windows and doors, and identifying the forces used to move these objects

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Investigating how the design of age-appropriate sporting equipment such as paddles, plastic bats and racquets helps to produce stronger pushes and pulls

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Recognising that pushing or pulling an object can start or stop its motion, or change its direction of travel

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Exploring ways that the shape of modelling dough can be changed when pushed or pulled

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Designing playground equipment, toys or games, and representing the push and pull forces involved, using models, digital drawings or role-play

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Pushes and pulls are forces that can change an object’s movement or shape and can be represented in terms of strength and direction
Elaboration: Exploring how traditional Asian toys and games such as a kendama, Daruma Otoshi and hanetsuki are played using a push or a pull

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Identifying how sounds are made, associating some of them with something vibrating, and then investigating how sound energy makes things vibrate, such as when speaking, using tuning forks, observing vibrations produced by a ‘twanged’ ruler held on a desk, experimenting with different ways of holding or positioning the ruler to produce observably different vibrations and sounds, and observing music speakers

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Designing and making instruments that produce different sounds, such as drums, rainsticks, thongophones and box guitars, and using them to build vocabulary such as ‘loudness’ and ‘pitch’ to describe the sounds

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Exploring different ways to produce sound using familiar objects, and actions such as striking, blowing, scraping, plucking and shaking

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Making earmuffs from a variety of different materials to investigate which provides the best insulation against sound

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Finding patterns between the pitch of a sound and features of the object that produced it, or between the volume of a sound and the strength of the vibrations that produced it

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Sound can make materials vibrate and vibrating materials can make sound; different actions can be used to produce sounds of varying pitch and volume
Elaboration: Discussing situations where echoes are produced and exploring how some people with vision impairment, and animals such as dolphins and bats, use echolocation to locate objects in their environments

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Asking questions about everyday objects and the materials these are made from, such as ‘What can shoes be made from?’ and exploring materials that can be used to make shoes (e.g. leather, wood, fur, plastic) and materials that cannot be used to make shoes (e.g. glass)

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Asking questions that can be explored, such as how animals meet their needs in particular places: ‘Where does it shelter? Where does it get water from?’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Posing questions to explore patterns and relationships about the appearance or position of celestial objects in space across time, such as ‘I wonder if the Moon will look the same tomorrow or next week as it does today?’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Making predictions before fieldwork, such as about which plants and animals might be observed in the school grounds

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Making predictions about explorations, such as ‘I think a plant will die if it doesn’t get enough water’

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Experiences can be used as a basis for posing questions to explore observed patterns and relationships, and to make predictions
Elaboration: Making predictions based on experience, such as about what might occur when tissue paper is pulled with different amounts of force

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Following safe procedures to record a plant’s seasonal changes by taking photographs, videos, drawings or making measurements

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Exploring different ways of investigating science questions through guided discussion

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Following steps in a guided investigation to determine how different objects move when pushed or pulled or suggesting steps for setting up and packing away equipment

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Following visual or verbal steps to construct a musical instrument or manipulate a material

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Suggesting safe procedures to observe the Sun, and taking measurements such as drawing chalk lines and using a length of string to measure shadows

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Scientific questions and predictions can be investigated safely by following procedures that have sequenced steps
Elaboration: Suggesting the materials and equipment that could be used to test predictions and measure the loudness of sounds made by different objects

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations are made using the senses and recorded, including informal measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Exploring what an observation is, and different ways to make observations, through guided discussion

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations are made using the senses and recorded, including informal measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Safely following instructions to record the touch, smell, sight or sound of materials and explaining why it is not appropriate to taste materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations are made using the senses and recorded, including informal measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Using senses (except for taste), binoculars or magnifying glasses to identify plants and animals, and recording observations using numbers, dots or drawings

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations are made using the senses and recorded, including informal measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Using informal measurements to measure and record the change in shape or movement of an object using handspans, blocks, pencil lengths or a length of string

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations are made using the senses and recorded, including informal measurements, using digital tools as appropriate
Elaboration: Exploring how digital tools can be used to make and record observations, such as simple clap-o-meter apps that measure sound volume, time-lapse digital photography for observing the apparent movement of celestial objects or slow-motion videos for observing a vibrating ruler

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Using provided tables to record how an object moves in a straight line

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Suggesting tables or visual models that could be used to record weather or seasonal changes across days, months or a year

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Using, with guidance, provided tables, visual models or physical models to record how far a material can stretch before tearing

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Grouping the common features of plants and animals

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Finding patterns in the sounds that are made by different objects such as saucepan lids of different sizes or elastic bands of different thicknesses

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Data and information can be sorted and ordered using provided tables and organisers, and visual or physical models, to show simple patterns
Elaboration: Sorting and ordering the changing appearance of the Moon to show a monthly cycle

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Comparing observations of weather at different times of day with those of others, and making predictions about weather patterns in the next week

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Comparing observations of different ways to physically change a material, such as by cutting and folding different types of paper, and exploring further questions to investigate physical changes to different materials

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Identifying differences between observations of plants and animals by different people

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Comparing, with guidance, observations with predictions about the way similar and different objects move

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Identifying, after exploration, further questions that arise from comparing observations of sound with observations of others and considering if everyone senses sound in the same way

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations can be compared to predictions and the observations of others, which may lead to further questions being identified
Elaboration: Suggesting, with guidance, reasons for differences between tracking methods recognised by Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples to identify tracks or plants, and the counting of animals by students

Subject: Science
ContentDescription: Observations, findings and ideas can be shared with others by using everyday and some scientific vocabulary
